questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You manage a virtual network named VNet1 that is hosted in the West US Azure region.
VNet1 hosts two virtual machines named VM1 and VM2 that run Windows Server.
You need to inspect all the network traffic from VM1 to VM2 for a period of three hours.
Solution: From Azure Network Watcher, you create a connection monitor.
Does this meet the goal?

comments.content: the reason why it's not packet capture is it's specifically from vm1 to vm2, which connection monitor does.
Packet Capture fits this requirement, as you can filter which traffic to capture (local ip, local port, remote ip, remote port).
You can use packet capture for inspecting traffic from VM1 to VM2 , if you configure it to select Target Machine as VM2 and use the filter for Remote IP to be the IP of VM1
It seems like you can't monitor "ALL" traffic with Network monitor. You have to specify an interval for it to poll. If you poll it every 10 seconds (or whatever) you don't have ALL the traffic

discussion.content:
Correct: No
Connection monitor has no interval and only monitors ONE src/dst port (not all)
I think the answer is No. Packet capture is more suited for traffic inspection: https://www.petri.com/capturing-inspecting-traffic-azure-networks
No is right

There are several versions of this question. The following are the possible Correct and Incorrect solutions. 

Correct solution: Meets the goal.
-Solution: From Azure Network Watcher, you create a packet capture.

Incorrect solution: Does not meet the goal. 
-Solution: From Azure Monitor, you create a metric on Network In and Network Out.

-Solution: From Azure Network Watcher, you create a connection monitor.

-Solution: From Performance Monitor, you create a Data Collector Set (DCS).

comments.content:
Azure suggests to use monitoring network communication between two virtual machines using Connection Monitor. 
Reference: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/network-watcher/connection-monitor

Answer is Yes
as per below definition
The Connection Monitor feature in Azure Network Watcher is now generally available in all public regions. Connection Monitor provides you RTT values on a per-minute granularity. You can monitor a direct TCP connection from a virtual machine to a virtual machine, FQDN, URI, or IPv4 address.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/network-watcher/frequently-asked-questions
Please note it mentioned inspection Inspection is possible only by packet capture...So answer is No

Correct answer: No
Packet Capture enables you to capture all traffic on a VM in your virtual networt

Connection Monitor allows you to monitor connectivity and latency between a VM and another network resource.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/network-watcher/frequently-asked-questions

Answer should be No:

Network Watcher packet capture allows you to create capture sessions to track traffic to and from a virtual machine. Filters are provided for the capture session to ensure you capture only the traffic you want. Packet capture helps to diagnose network anomalies, both reactively, and proactively. 

Network Watcher Connection Monitor enables you to configure and track connection reachability, latency, and network topology changes. If there is an issue, it tells you why it occurred and how to fix it.

Offical documentation: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/network-watcher/network-watcher-packet-capture-manage-portal

Answer is NO.
Use Packet Capture here.

It should be NO...
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/network-watcher/network-watcher-packet-capture-manage-portal

https://www.itexams.com/exam/AZ-101

Answer is Yes.

The Connection Monitor in Network Watcher is similar to
Connection Troubleshoot, in that it uses the same mechanism
to test the connection between an Azure VM or App Gateway
and another endpoint. The difference is that Connection
Monitor provides ongoing connection monitoring, whereas
Connection Troubleshoot only provides a point-in-time test.
Data from Connection Monitor is surfaced in Azure
Monitor. 
***Charts show key metrics such as round-trip time and
probe failures. Azure Monitor can also be used to configure
alerts, triggered by connection failures or a drop in
performance.
The answer is no. Connection Monitor only gives a 'red/green' status for a given connection, whereas the question states you need to see all traffic.

Answer is "No"
Solution: From Azure Network Watcher, you create a packet capture.

discussion.content: Should be Yes. And "Connection Monitor" answer should be No, as pointed out in comment section.

Same question with 4 different solutions.

You manage a virtual network named VNet1 that is hosted in the West US Azure region.
VNet1 hosts two virtual machines named VM1 and VM2 that run Windows Server.
You need to inspect all the network traffic from VM1 to VM2 for a period of three hours.

Solution: From Azure Network Watcher, you create a connection monitor.
Does this meet the goal? No

Solution: From Performance Monitor, you create a Data Collector Set (DCS).
Does this meet the goal? No

Solution: From Azure Monitor, you create a metric on Network In and Network Out.
Does this meet the goal? No

Solution: From Azure Network Watcher, you create a packet capture.
Does this meet the goal? Yes

Azure suggests to use Connection Monitor to monitor network communication between two virtual machines
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/network-watcher/connection-monitor

packet captures with Azure Network Watcher
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/network-watcher/network-watcher-packet-capture-manage-portal
Connection Monitor
https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/updates/general-availability-azure-network-watcher-connection-monitor-in-all-public-regions/
Please read the discription then choose your right answer.
Yes for me

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/network-watcher/frequently-asked-questions 
explains the differences:

*Connection Troubleshoot enables a one-time connectivity and latency check between a VM and another network resource.
*Packet Capture enables you to capture all traffic on a VM in your virtual network.

It is obvious that Packet Capture will show all the traffic between VMs versus Connection Monitor that checks the connectivity on a given time
Answer is A: Packet capture allows us to create packet capture sessions to track traffic to and from VM's and helps in detecting anomalies.

Packet capture options captures all traffic from one vm. Which means it will capture all outgoing from vm1 irrespective of it's destination (might be an user trying to hit p*hub, who cares!). 
To capture packets only towards vm2, we need connection monitor

Since we have to inspect all the traffic, Packet Capture is better. Through connection monitor, you can see the data for Connection Reachability , latency etc You can see data till last 30 days. However Packet capture helps to diagnose network anomalies, Other uses include gathering network statistics, gaining information on network intrusions, to debug client-server communication, and much more. Also you can use filter to set the IP address of VM from which the traffic needs to be monitored.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/network-watcher/network-watcher-packet-capture-manage-portal#:~:text=Local%20IP%20address%3A%20Filters%20the,IP%20address%20matches%20this%20value.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/network-watcher/connection-monitor
Its say connection Monitor is correct answer

The answer is A. Advanced filtering options and fine-tuned controls, such as the ability to set time and size limitations, provide versatility. The capture can be stored in Azure Storage, on the VM's disk, or both. You can then analyze the capture file using several standard network capture analysis tools. Learn more about packet capture.

Connection Monitor 
The CONNECTION MONITOR tests the connection at a point in time, rather than monitoring it over time, as connection. 


Whereas, Packet Capture enables you to capture all traffic on a VM in your virtual network.

You need to inspect all the network traffic from VM1 to VM2 for a period of three hours.
Solution: From Azure Network Watcher, you create a connection monitor.
Does this meet the goal?
No

You need to inspect all the network traffic from VM1 to VM2 for a period of three hours.
Solution: From Azure Network Watcher, you create a packet capture.
Does this meet the goal?

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You manage a virtual network named VNet1 that is hosted in the West US Azure region.
VNet1 hosts two virtual machines named VM1 and VM2 that run Windows Server.
You need to inspect all the network traffic from VM1 to VM2 for a period of three hours.
Solution: From Azure Network Watcher, you create a packet capture.
Does this meet the goal?

HOTSPOT -
You have an Azure subscription named Subscription1 that contains the virtual networks in the following table.
//IMG//

Subscription1 contains the virtual machines in the following table.
//IMG//

In Subscription1, you create a load balancer that has the following configurations:
✑ Name: LB1
✑ SKU: Basic
✑ Type: Internal
✑ Subnet: Subnet12
✑ Virtual network: VNET1
For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
For starters, the LB can't be in Subnet12 and VNet1, as stated in the question. Something's gotta give, COME ON...

Assuming Subnet11 and VNet1:
Yes, No, No (given answer is correct)

Assuming Subnet12 and VNet2:
No, No, No (given answer is wrong)

comments.content: If it is Subnet12 and VNet2 - then No, No and Yes right... VM5 and VM6 are in Subnet12 on VNET2 and LB1 is being configured for the same. Then isn't it a case LB1 can balance the traffic between VM5 and VM6?
But VM5 and VM6 are not on an Availability Set and LB1 sku is Basic. If it was standard LB then is a different story.

comments.content: B.I mean SKU is 'Basic'

Its No,No,No.

explanation for 1 and 2:
Referring to configuration of internal LB:

- Name: LB1
- SKU: Basic
- Type: Internal
- Subnet: Subnet12
- Virtual network: VNET1
The subnet refers to backend pool whereas Virtual Network refers to what's used in the front end (and backend is a subnet in same virtual network).

[https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/load-balancer/quickstart-load-balancer-standard-internal-portal?tabs=option-1-create-internal-load-balancer-standard]

For 3rd one,its No due to 2 reasons:
A. The LB configuration itself is incorrect as its mentioned subnet 12(used for backend pool configuration) is part of VNET2 whereas loadbalancer is attempted to be deployed in VNET1.
B. Type of Loadbalancer is Basic which only accepts VMSS or Av Sets as Backend Pool.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/load-balancer/skus
Has to be a typo, vnet and LB have to be in same vnet plus subnet 12 was stated in vnet2.
no, no, no looks better answer since subnet 12 is in vnet2, Load balancer is vnet1

answer is no, no , no

choices.C: Select Allow gateway transit on VNet1.
choices.D: Download and re-install the VPN client configuration package on Client1.
choices.A: Select Allow gateway transit on VNet2.

questions.question_text:
You have an Azure subscription named Subscription1 that contains two Azure virtual networks named VNet1 and VNet2. VNet1 contains a VPN gateway named
VPNGW1 that uses static routing. There is a site-to-site VPN connection between your on-premises network and VNet1.
On a computer named Client1 that runs Windows 10, you configure a point-to-site VPN connection to VNet1.
You configure virtual network peering between VNet1 and VNet2. You verify that you can connect to VNet2 from the on-premises network. Client1 is unable to connect to VNet2.
You need to ensure that you can connect Client1 to VNet2.
What should you do?

comments.content: where did you see "before" statement? how do you make sure, these actions are done in a lineer order? I did not see the question mentioning that.
the question is sneaky, the peering was setup after teh point-to-site vpn was was setup, hence re-installing the VPN client is the corrrect answer

NO it is not implied .Gateway Transmit is used with allow remote gateway
. These two are used together to grant access to resources that are not directly not in contact with azure ( here Vnet)
S2S is working indicating that Gateway Transit is already set up. Only thing remains to to download & install the VPN client again
Okay... But in this case, how is it that S2S works just fine?

discussion.content:
Correct answer is D
The problem states that you have created the point-to-site VPN before you configured peering.

Clients using Windows can access directly peered VNets, but the VPN client must be downloaded again if any changes are made to VNet peering or the network topology.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/vpn-gateway/vpn-gateway-about-point-to-site-routing
this answer seems correct, since your on prem network can reach vnet2 means that "Allow Gateway transit" is already enabled.

Correct
If we consider the statement - You verify that you can connect to VNet2 from the on-premises network - this clear A,B,C out of the scope, because we already have it ok with the S2S connection. So something is on Client1 that need to be fixed.

Clients using Windows can access directly peered VNets, but the VPN client must be downloaded again if any changes are made to VNet peering or the network topology. Non-Windows clients can access directly peered VNets. Access is not transitive and is limited to only directly peered VNets.

This question is wrong; VPN gateway uses static routing (non BGP). So the access would be limited to vnet1 for S2S as well. Transit routing is possible only if you enable BGP. First you need to enable BGP, then reinstall client config.

Folks, the answer is correct (D). Please read this link. The documentation states it - https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/vpn-gateway/vpn-gateway-about-point-to-site-routing

"Clients using Windows can access directly peered VNets, but the VPN client must be downloaded again if any changes are made to VNet peering or the network topology. Non-Windows clients can access directly peered VNets. Access is not transitive and is limited to only directly peered VNets."

If you make a change to the topology of your network and have Windows VPN clients, the VPN client package for Windows clients must be downloaded and installed again in order for the changes to be applied to the client.
Answer C is correct..if there are any changes made in VPN at Azure VN ..need to reinstall VPN client on client side

Static Routes are not supported for Point to Site connections
For the Resource Manager deployment model, you must have a RouteBased VPN type for your gateway. For the classic deployment model, you need a dynamic gateway. We do not support Point-to-Site for static routing VPN gateways or PolicyBased VPN gateways.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/vpn-gateway/point-to-site-about

First I also though that it's a C but after c677212's answer everything goes ok. As explained in question that you can connect to VM2 from on premises which means you already have VP1 transit configured.
So is it C or D... have C but don't understand why re-installing client would solve anything.

comments.content: Yes ur correct Sheru..

Bcz thats in the documentation
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/vpn-gateway/vpn-gateway-about-point-to-site-routing
Specifically, this section. "Clients using Windows can access directly peered VNets, but the VPN client must be downloaded again if any changes are made to VNet peering or the network topology."

discussion.content:
The answer should be C: 

We want to traverse from : ClientVM -> VNET1 -> VNET2 

For this, we need to, first of all, allow Gateway transit on Vnet1 which will traverse the request from ClientVM to VNET2 and vice-versa. 

Post that we can download the VPN client and connect to the VNET2. 

Official Documentation: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/vpn-gateway/vpn-gateway-peering-gateway-transit

Correct answer is C 
Select Allow gateway transit on VNet1.

Coz it uses peering not vpn gateway between vnets

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/vpn-gateway/vpn-gateway-about-point-to-site-routing

comments.content: For me, "You verify that you can connect to VNet2 from the on-premises network." tells you that it is not a network issue, but instead, the problem lies in the VPN side with this specific computer. It would be helpful if they told you just how you verified that you could connect to VNet2.

discussion.content:
Correct.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/vpn-gateway/vpn-gateway-about-point-to-site-routing

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You manage a virtual network named VNet1 that is hosted in the West US Azure region.
VNet1 hosts two virtual machines named VM1 and VM2 that run Windows Server.
You need to inspect all the network traffic from VM1 to VM2 for a period of three hours.
Solution: From Performance Monitor, you create a Data Collector Set (DCS).
Does this meet the goal?

comments.content:
Why is this? Because of this key wording ''all traffic''? 

I've come across this one several times and I'm afraid that though you may be right ... in the real exam it'd be marked down as Connection Monitor.

discussion.content: A note: The justification is that the right feature is the Packet Capture from the Network Watcher, but it is still B (= No) as the correct answer.

comments.content: Connection Monitor monitors communication at regular intervals. It informs you of changes in reachability and latency
Connection-monitor you mean...

discussion.content:
Answer is B
With an data collector set you can count specified network traffic, bu you cannot inspect it. For this you would need a network monitor.
Or, of course, Packet Capture.
Connection troubleshoot. Under Network Watcher...

questions.answer_description:
Use the Connection Monitor feature of Azure Network Watcher.
References:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/network-watcher/network-watcher-monitoring-overview
